title: At close of business on 31 December 2020, will Apple be the most valuable publicly traded company in the world?
possible_answers: Yes, the most valuable in the world
No, but the most valuable in the United States
correct_answer: Yes, the most valuable in the world
preds: Adjusting by 1% in both factors given latest from share prices in the closing minutes of 2020.
Exceeds Saudi Aramco by usd 0.3 Trillion at the moment.

Today's share price of $137.37 (@ 11h31 EST) exceeds the previous high of $134.18 (20200901) so there is a high probability AAPL will be the most valuable publicly traded company in the world by 20201231, i.e. two days time, unless something very unexpected happens

Apple's 2020 share price (against which "value" could be defined) is a fair margin ahead of Microsoft and Amazon in Q3 and looks, with Christmas sale trends over the last few years, likely to remain so in Q4. https://ycharts.com/companies/AAPL/market_cap
https://ycharts.com/companies/MSFT/market_cap
https://ycharts.com/companies/AMZN/market_cap Alternatively, market cap could be used to define "value", with the same results. https://spendmenot.com/blog/largest-public-companies/ There is an outside possibility that Amazon may move ahead given 2020's COVID driven boost but this seems likely to be matched by Apple's Christmas sales bunt. The question of "most valuable in the US" is harder to answer given that Apple Operations International is registered in Ireland.

Apple's announcement about moving into producing cars with new battery technology has given the shares a boost. Seehttps://reut.rs/3rnGyyW. Current share price @ US$131.55 (@ 20201222 11h55EST) takes it to within $7 of its all time high, which would confirm it as the most valuable publicly listed company in the world based on market capitalisation. Year end book squaring by traders aside, this should hold for the next 9 days.

No, it will be close with Microsoft but Microsoft should have the advantage going into the end of the year.  The profits with Azure and CovID lockdowns have caused WFH opportunities to spike, leading to increased profits for MSFT.  In addition AAPL does not plan to announce Iphone 12 sales until early next year which will most likely affect their stock price (negatively).
It is looking like it will still be the most valuable in the world at the end of the year. With Christmas around the corner, sales are probably going to boost stocks at the end of the year.

I think this one's going to be tighter than the crowd thinks. Admittedly, I'm late to the game here, but if my calculations are correct, Saudi Aramco last closed with a market cap of 7.08T Saudi Riyal, which is about 1.887T US dollars. As of this moment, Apple is trading at about 2.09T US dollars market cap. That's not super tight, but we have another two weeks to go. Now that a vaccine is moving, at least in the US, the price of oil might move up, which could be enough to boost Saudi Aramco to first place. Still, Apple's low in the last month was about 116, which would require about a 6.5% drop from its price right now. And even then, it'd still be at about 1.98T. Saudi Aramco would need to jump by about the same to make it a dead heat. I think there's a chance, but not a great one. In any case, there's no chance that Apple's not the most valuable in the US. So it's just the top two choices battling it out.

This question is basically "will Saudi Aramco stock outperform AAPL stock between now and EOY."  With Saudi Aramco being heavily tied to the price of oil, and an imminent COVID vaccine spurring a potential boost in economic activity, it's possible that energy stocks finish 2020 on a strong note, but AAPL has been a very strong stock YTD and I weight it slightly more likely that AAPL continues to outperform into EOY

As of 10 Dec, Apple continues to rise in the market beyond others. This combined with the crowd view leads me to adjust my forecast.
https://www.theverge.com/2020/7/31/21350154/apple-worlds-most-valuable-company-saudi-aramco
Has such a big lead over Microsoft it is hard to see them being overtaken.

There will be no earnings reports before December 31, 2020. Thus the value of the company is less likely to waver.
After looking at the next most valuable companies, I realized that the only other companies that could come close to challenging Apple for the top spot are; Microsoft, Alphabet and Amazon. Thus, if Apple loses its status as the most valuable public company by 31 December 2020, it will be a U.S. company that does it, therefore...
Increase prob. of yes by 1%
Decrease prob. of no, but in U.S. by 2%
Increase prob. of no by 1%

AAPL has pretty much locked up the most valuable in US question. I'm not as optimistic about it wrapping up the most valuable globally. With the combination of the inevitable COVID surge post-thanksgiving and low chances of further economic stimulus while Trump is crying foul, there is a good chance of a <10% market correction before the end of the year. A market correction would probably not impact ARAMCO as much as the March one did - shipping and other transport are continuing across asia and other parts of the world that are dealing with the pandemic. 
I think AAPL is still a good chance here, but it's certainly not a certainty yet.
I could see Amazon eclipsing them after the holiday season as a low possibility

https://www.gjopen.com/ The time horizon is short and the current trend points in that direction. I can’t see many scenarios where that changes: Some event that tanks the stock (forbidden in China, ...) or some other company skyrocketing its valuation because of some new technology or change of the rules to its advantage.

A big revision to my previous forecast: Market Cap figures for Saudi Aramco provided by Google are totally different than those of Bloomberg's that are used here! I did a lengthy simulation to provide an answer. Here's what I did: I fetched daily open prices of Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and Saudi Aramco for several years from Yahoo Finance. I turned the daily prices into logarithmic daily returns and calculated median and mean absolute deviation (MAD) for each of the four series. The median and MAD are the maximum likelihood estimate parameters for a two-parameter Laplace distribution (aka double exponential distribution) , which is a very good distribution to model daily logarithmic returns of various assets. See how the empirical kernel density estimates and maximum likelihood Laplace distribution probability density curve align nicely in the graph that I did: https://pasteboard.co/JzCO9Gd.png Next, I checked the amount of trading days left this year. This is 39. I then proceeded to do a random walk simulation of laplace returns for 39 observations. Next I put these observations into exponent function to get the percentage returns from logarithmic returns and calculated the product of all 39 elements of this vector. I repeated the above procedure for 10000 times for each of the different random walks. These simulations are the year end prices for each of the stocks. Finally, I checked the number of shares outstanding for each of the companies, multiplied simulated year end share values with the outstanding shares and for Saudi Aramco also multiplied it with SAR/USD exchange rate. The probability was now easy to calculate. I have a data frame of 10000 rows with four columns corresponding to market prices of each company. I calculated the share of these 10000 simulations, in which AAPL is the most valuable and that is 79,3 %. I did not calculate betas for the stocks - so basically only idiosyncratic risk is present in the simulation. With MSFT, AAPL and AMZN, this might be a problem, but as they are further a part in current Market cap than Aramco and Apple, I suppose it's not such a big deal. Most of the cases in which APPL is not the largest are due to ARAMCO and that is in a different industry and country. !!!!! THE _NO_ CATEGORY IS ERRONEOUS !!!!! The event probabilities in the question do not sum up to one, because these are not mutually exclusive events. If AAPL is more valuable than MSFT and AMZN, but less than ARAMCO, then in this case AAPL is not the most valuable company in the world so it's a "NO" case. But at the same time it is a "No, but the most valuable in the United States" case. The correct last category ensuring mutual exclusivity should be: 
"Not the most valuable anywhere AND not the most valuable in the US, but the most valuable elsewhere". Ideally, there should be four categories to account for each permutation 
(the most valuable in the US, the most valuable elsewhere): 
1. (TRUE, FALSE) = No, but the most valuable in the United States, 
2. (TRUE, TRUE) = Yes, the most valuable in the world, 
3. (FALSE, FALSE) = Not the most valuable anywhere,
4. (FALSE, TRUE) = Not the most valuable in the United States, but the most valuable elsewhere.

Amazon has expressed a base relative strength in overall growth during the pandemic period that is hot on the heels of Apple. Especially as we move into the holiday season, if there are indicators that Amazon is able to maintain such strength (particular in the face of other eCommerce players like Wal-Mart making big moves), then It could experience another significant jump - perhaps even pushing it past Apple. Meanwhile, Apple is less likely to continue on the same trajectory, at least in such disruptive terms.

No earnings releases to be published in the remaining time and change the first place holder.  The average volatility of Apple, Google, Amazon and Saudi Aramco is not enough for changing the first place either. Lastly, no major announcements in sight that I know of that could change the first place.

Aramco could do it if there was a major supply disruption (conflict like Azeri/Armenia if it expanded). But for now it’s Apple. From the Economist 
“Apple will at last reveal its new iPhone models today. As always, the firm has kept tight-lipped about the devices’ stand-out features (other than naming the launch event “Hi, Speed”). Many expect them to be able to connect to 5G networks, the zippy next generation of mobile technology. This, analysts predict, will trigger a new iPhone “supercycle”, with sales growing at rates in the double digits. Such predictions have helped Apple’s share price to surge by nearly 60% this year, driving its market capitalisation above $2trn. Yet more cautious voices say that the moment is not yet ripe. Super-fast 5G networks are not yet widespread, least of all in America, and consumers tend to hold on to their devices longer nowadays. In the midst of a pandemic many lack the cash for a new iSomething. But if the tech titan has timed the release correctly, it will be a sweet Apple-picking season.“

Really this question is: will the US have another major market crash by 31 Dec. It's possible, and another crash is certainly coming soon, but I think they can keep things juiced that long. The biggest likelihood is that the election, or the fallout from the election, will crash the market.

Apple is currently the most valuable company in the world. The only companies that might overtake it in the next 4 months appear to be ARAMCO and AMZN. I expect it to remain one of the most valuable companies in the world but see significant downside risk. First, it is only a few hundred billion dollars more valuable than ARAMCO. While this may seem like a lot, AAPL can and often does shed a hundred billion dollars in market cap on a single bad trading day. I also see serious risk of AAPL dropping in value by more than 10% in the next few months because 1) The US economy will continue to be hit by the pandemic. 2) AAPL is currently trading at an extremely high P/E relative to historical prices, which combined with the bad economy could see a drop. AAPL's largest domestic competitor, AMZN, continues to gain market cap, and although it sees many of the problems I outline for AAPL above, it appears to be more robust to a bad economy. AMZN could pass AAPL as it gains market share as more local businesses shut down, and if AAPL drops in value due to a broad market selloff. Regarding ARAMCO, I know very little. I'm assigned a 15% chance of ARAMCO passing AAPL since I think ARAMCO is already hit with low oil prices that could be reversed and will not face a broad market sell of risk that high-priced US companies like AAPL may face.

At the moment Apple is the most valued company in the world with 2.1T dollar. Second in America is AMZN with 1.7T dollar , and second in the world is ARAMCO with 1.8T dollar . So a few things are happening with Apple and in the world:
(1) Epic games is in a battle with Apple concerning their high fee (of 30%) for in game expenses. Seeing that 2/9th of Apples revenues comes from services. This can have influence on their revenue stream if they loss the battle or give in with a lower free.
(2) WeChat ban for American companies. So Apple users in China are not allowed anymore to download WeChat. This is a huge part of the mobile lives of Chinese people, that probably sales will drop in China. China market is 15% of the revenues of Apple and sales of mobile phones is 4/9th of Apples total revenue
(3) Economic crisis is hitting high end products and the mobile market is mature (compared to the 2008 crisis).
(4) Last quarter was better than expected (words of Apple). During the quarantine people get help from governments and having more time to spend their money, so they get future big expenses to now. In the upcoming months the government support will be less and future sales are all ready being done. All with all, I think Apple is overpriced. If that translate to a lower growth of downturn before the end of the year is difficult to say. Money markets don't have much better options to go to. To loss the status of most valued, Apple has to loss 20% in value of AMZN of ARAMCO have to go up in value with 25% (or a combination of those two). With the points mentioned above Apple will loss in the worst case 20% of future revenue, see also market cap. ARAMCO is in a vulnerable position (see oil market), AMZN is growing fast and in the best scenario will grown this year another 40% (in the same rate as the rest of the year).  Combining the the odds: 75% - 5% - 20%

On 17 Aug, the largest market caps are Apple                                   - 1.97 T
Aramco                               - 1.78 T
Amazon                              - 1.58 T
Microsoft                            - 1.58 T
Alphabet                             - 1.02 T The answer buckets are:
Yes (meaning Apple will be most valuable)
No, but most valuable in the US (meaning Apple will be the most valuable in the US, but Aramco would have beaten Apple)
No (meaning some other US company, i.e. Microsoft or Amazon could have beaten Apple) Now history is on Apples side, they have dominated the market cap charts over the last decade - maybe spending 75% of the time as the most valuable company in the world. But Microsoft has been giving Apple tough competition over the last couple of years - along with the listing of Aramco. Amazon will benefit from the pandemic headwind.  Aramco faces multiple problems - but their ridiculous 1.5% float makes it easy for the price to run up.  Hence my baseline estimates of
60% - Apple remains most valuable
15% - Aramco becomes most valuable
25% - Either Microsoft or Amazon becomes most valuable

Starting from the bottom "No" - there's a meaningful chance that Apple drops due to both an overheated market _and_ regulatory challenges (or becomes collateral in a US/China spat). This would make it less than Aramco (which wouldn't be hit as much by a market correction) and also likely less than Amazon (which is also open to regulatory challenges, but not as exposed to a China spat, _and_ has the benefit of AWS being almost impervious to all of the above. Moving up to "No, but the most valuable in the United States" - this is basically a bet on a market correction this year that does not recover with the pace the COVID-collapse did. The market correction is definitely possible, and if it happens the recovery will be unlikely to have the same shape (several reasons for this). Finally up the top "Yes, the most valuable in the world". Based on the two above scenarios, this _should_ seem the most unlikely. It's a bet that there won't be a market correction (dropping Apple below Aramco) and a slightly smaller bet that there won't be a regulatory/China issue that drops Apple below Amazon.  While I say it _should_ be the most unlikely, the last six months (and arguably six years!) of public markets have taught me that we live in extraordinary times. So...weirdly, I'm giving it a 50% chance. Leaving the bulk of the rest to a bet on an overall market correction that brings down both Amazon and Apple under Aramco, and a small chance that regulatory/China issues drop it under Amazon.

Apple is by far the most profitable of these companies (Apple, Alphabet [Google], Amazon & Microsoft).
Apple has also just overtaken Aramco as the world's most valuable publicly traded company and will be that on 31st December 2020.

With election's looming, Congress is unlikely to agree on much more stimuli packages, as Democrats fear that an economy in better shape will disproportionately help Trump. Amazon will prove more resilient to this - as well as Covid-19- than Apple and Saudi Aramco and be the most valuable company in the world at the end of the year.

Saudi Aramco and oil will continue to be pushed low for the remainder of the year.

Apple Aug 14 closed at 459.63USD/share with market cap =$1.965T
Aramco closed at 33.50 SAR with a market cap of 6.7T SAR and there are 3.7503SAR/$ today = $1.786T Market cap.
Aramco is under pressure and will likely be thru year end. Apple has a new product cycle to launch for holiday.
Dollar value is likely to continue to errode which may make Apple's job harder.

The biggest threat to the Apple brand "designed in California" is likely the US-China trade conflict, where Apple products are for the largest part made from Chinese components, assembled in Chinese sweat shops.
If the WH administration (current and next) pursue the current path eroding US supply chains in mainland China, Apple may at a certain point in time, with demand increasing or at least stable, simply be cut off of supply. With some Apple business meanwhile "immaterial" (TV, streaming, App store, ...), there is still a risk of turnover being cut by at least 50% for a quarter.
The valuation of Apple may shrink by 30% or more on an incident like this. Others of the US FAANG stocks are more resilient to US-China trade relations, such as amazon, which could easily overtake Apple's valuation.
However, this scenario has a probability of ~10%, i'd say, but if it materializes, it will be devastating to AAPL. Another threat looms from a legal battle with game developer Epic Games over removal of Fortnite from the Apple App Store over micropayments. https://gamerant.com/fortnite-vs-apple-microtransaction-ios-phones-legal-lawsuit/ "The battle for Fortnite might result in some landmark rulings that could affect Apple's business model and mean a great deal to games with microtransactions all across the market."
[...]
"The most drastic and immediate consequence that could come from this case is direct action against Apple by the government. If the case is ruled in Epic's favor, Apple might see some significant punishment for trying to monopolize companies on its store to make a profit. A court order could force Apple to repay damages to Epic and companies like it or to restructure its holdings. It might even result in a deeper investigation into Apple's business practices, since the previously mentioned Congressional hearing indicates that there's plenty of distrust pointed at the company already." Even facebook is said to have joined a boycott against Apple, whatever this means. Will have to follow up this one.
